p: Changes in DEMs in liver and skeletal muscle of ob/ ob mice, as well as in the blood, suggested higher oxidative stress in the ob/ ob mice. In skeletal muscle, we identified anserine and carnosine, which are dipeptides composed of beta-alanine and histidine, as decreased DEMs in skeletal muscle of ob/ ob mice. Anserine and carnosine are antioxidant factors involved in the degradation of lipid peroxide and are abundant in skeletal muscle ( Kohen et al., 1988; Boldyrev et al., 2013). The decrease in these metabolites in ob/ ob mice suggested that lipid peroxide may accumulate in skeletal muscle cells of ob/ ob mice. In addition, both glutathione (GSH) and GSSG increased in the liver, and GSSG increased in the blood of ob/ ob mice, which may reflect the oxidative stress associated with higher energy production in ob/ ob mice ( Tangvarasittichai, 2015).
